Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Training and Text Collection as a Vehicle for Recruiting and Retaining Endangered Language Fieldworkers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
There are an estimated 7,000 languages in the world and linguists anticipate at least half of those will go silent by the end of the current century. A key intellectual challenge is thus documenting the language and associated scientific knowledge before the 3,000 threatened languages cease to be spoken. This project addresses the challenge using an exploratory modification of a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU)-style model focused on students at or near the onset of graduate study in linguistics. The focus on early-career linguists is intended to shape their research trajectories and produce continuing long-term research results as the project participants advance in their graduate and post-graduate careers and in turn train others. The project has the potential to increase the number of linguistic specialists in the United States focusing on underdocumented and endangered languages, an increase in technical capacity serving the national interest by keeping U.S. institutions at the forefront of scientific research on endangered languages. The project will recruit and train post-baccalaureate linguists in fieldwork methodology and language documentation. It will also enlist a postdoctoral researcher into the project. Second, the project will also result in documentation for multiple underdocumented and endangered languages, directly advancing scientific knowledge via the archived collection of texts from multiple endangered languages. These texts will provide researchers with a large corpus of connected natural speech, which will help to reveal grammatical properties of the languages, especially those where sentence structure (syntax) and pronunciation (phonology) interface, which has been shown from cross-linguistic investigations to display considerable complexity. Broader impacts include the training and mentoring of linguists from underrepresented groups, the fostering of international collaborations, and international research and fieldwork experience for early-career (post-baccalaureate and post-doctoral) scholars.

Led by two faculty from the University of California, Los Angeles and the Graduate Center, City University of New York, this project will develop a pipeline of junior scholar linguists working on African languages and new collaborations with African communities through the mechanism of in situ field research experiences in Ghana, resulting in actual, quality language documentation. The first phase will target "early career" graduate and prospective graduate students with interests in African languages, leveraging the 2018 Institute on Collaborative Language Research (CoLang 2018) to train students in the technical aspects of language documentation. This will be followed in the second phase by hands-on training in which the participants will work directly with members of four endangered language communities in Ghana, targeting the North Guang or Ghana-Togo Mountain languages. The entire project team will work one-on-one with speakers and record, transcribe, translate and analyze a collection of texts, which will come from a number of genres, such as folktales, personal reminiscences, family histories, and children's stories. These efforts will augment the existing literature on the targeted languages in terms of their lexical, morphological, syntactic and phonological properties, as these languages are generally underdocumented, or even undocumented. Narratives involve speech in context, and are likely to show syntax-phonology interface effects, as well as other grammatical structures of interest. Moreover, the documentation will be a permanent record of important cultural and historical information, having broad applicability across fields and serving as the basis for future work on the languages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary:

EAGER: Training and Text Collection as a Vehicle for Recruiting and Retaining Endangered Language Fieldworkers (BCS 1748590)

 

This project sought to directly address two tightly interrelated problems by proposing a novel training program for recruiting graduate students into Africa-focused linguistic research. The first problem this project addressed is the continued lack of systematic documentary and descriptive materials on the vast majority of African languages.  The second problem is the declining number of US-based specialists in African languages.  Both issues are urgent because the pace of language extinction, both worldwide and in Africa, is rapidly accelerating.  Therefore, there is a critical need for linguists trained in fieldwork to focus on the documentation and description of African languages. 

 

With these issues in mind, the project had two principal goals. As a first goal, the project would produce documentary, descriptive, and analytical materials on two endangered and under-described African languages through in-country fieldwork. The research languages chosen were Avatime and Ikpana. The principal on-the-ground activities of the fieldwork goal involved text collection, structured elicitation, and analysis of grammatical phenomena in the two languages.  The second goal of the project was to recruit and train the next generation of Africa-focused linguists in the United States, scholars dedicated to the documentation, description, and analysis of African languages. The project involved the training of graduate and undergraduate students at American institutions on data collection techniques and community-based fieldwork.  There were four student participants selected (three early career graduate students and one undergraduate), in addition to the two Principal Investigators, a postdoctoral researcher, and a graduate student assistant, who made up the research team.

 

The student participants attended the CoLang summer institute in 2018, where they received initial training on linguistic fieldwork and language documentation. All members of the project team (the two Co-PIs, the postdoc, the four students, and the graduate student assistant) travelled to Ghana and carried out fieldwork and language documentation projects in the summer of 2018. Six of the eight participants returned to the field in the summer of 2019 to continue documentation of the Avatime and Ikpana languages. Following this return field trip, co-PIs Kandybowicz and Torrence continued to oversee and mentor students on their work on Avatime and Ikpana. Both Co-PIs additionally continued solo research on their target languages.

 

The intellectual merit of this project flows directly from the principal activities that team members were involved in.  First, the project resulted in the production of a novel collection of texts on languages for which there is little previous documentation.  The texts encompass a variety of genres (such as traditional stories, personal narratives, and songs) and constitute a permanent record of important cultural and linguistic aspects of the Avatime and Ikpana languages. Second, the project resulted in the documentation, description, and analysis of a wide variety of grammatical phenomena in the languages. The concrete results have been conference presentations, conference proceedings, journal articles, invited talks, graduate qualifying papers, and Ph.D. dissertations. Two book proposals with major international book publishers have been produced and are currently under review as well. Pending their acceptance, the books that were produced under the auspices of this grant will represent some of the first commercially available book publications on the target languages and will provide a venue for the dissemination of the texts collected, thus fostering a sense of vitality and pride among members of the community and catalyzing future efforts to maintain and sustain the languages. The hope is that efforts such as these will play a role in improving the languages’ endangered statuses, one of the broader impacts of the project.

 

The other broader impacts of the projects are tied directly to the project structure.  The project resulted in the training of four students in fieldwork methodology and community-based documentation practices over the course of two summers of fieldwork. These students are now independently researching the languages and at the conclusion of the summer of 2018, the participants had conducted novel research on endangered African languages in the field.  The students received additional training in the summer of 2019. This next generation of Africanists will continue to produce high quality research over the coming years, reversing the declining trend of US-based African scholarship.

 

The second major broader impact of the grant is that it resulted in the documentation of multiple endangered African languages through the collection of texts. These texts will serve as a community cultural resource into the future.
